maml:description.maml:para: Add one or more entities to an Azure Table.
Add one or more entities to an Azure Table, as an array of either Hashtables or PSObjects.
A context object created by New-AzDataTableContext, with authentication information for the table to operate on.
If the table should be created if it does not exist.
The entities to add to the table.
Overwrites provided entities if they exist.
A context object created by New-AzDataTableContext, with authentication information for the table to operate on.
If the table should be created if it does not exist.
The entities to add to the table.
Overwrites provided entities if they exist.
This cmdlet takes either an array of hashtables or psobjects as input to the Entity parameter, which can also be provided through the pipeline.

maml:alert.maml:para: The underlying Azure.Data.Tables SDK expects to work with DateTime fields in UTC format for conversion to DateTimeOffset objects. When submitting a DateTimeOffset object to the SDK, it will be converted to UTC timezone rather than preserving the existing timezone/offset info. Similarly, if a `DateTime` object is submitted in the entity with its Kind set to "local" or "unspecified", the SDK will return an error and state that `Azure SDK requires it to be UTC`. While there isn't any change needed to get `DateTimeOffset` objects to work with AzBobbyTables, the workaround for `DateTime` objects is to set the property to a new `DateTime` object with its `Kind` property set to `Utc`. e.g. `$obj.Time = $obj.Time.ToUniversalFormat()`. Related issue (https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net/issues/30644).

It is possible via the Azure Storage Explorer to set DateTime fields with offsets other than UTC/+00:00. Note that searches with queries set to type `DateTime` do properly calculate to a specific moment, and find equivilent moments. e.g. a `-Filter` set to `Time eq datetime'2023-12-26T18:05:40.5345634+00:00'` will match an entry where the Time property is set to `2023-12-26T17:05:40.5345634-01:00`.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Add the user "Bobby Tables" to a table using a connection string.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Context = New-AzDataTableContext -TableName $TableName -SharedAccessSignature $SAS PS C:\> $Users = @( >> @{ FirstName = 'Bobby'; LastName = 'Tables'; PartitionKey = 'Example'; RowKey = '1' }, >> @{ FirstName = 'Bobby Junior'; LastName = 'Tables'; PartitionKey = 'Example'; RowKey = '2' } ) PS C:\> Add-AzDataTableEntity -Entity $Users -Context $Context -Force

dev:remarks.maml:para: Add multiple users to a table using a shared access signature URL, overwriting any existing rows.

maml:description.maml:para: Clear all entities from an Azure Table.
Clear all entities from an Azure Table.
A context object created by New-AzDataTableContext, with authentication information for the table to operate on.
A context object created by New-AzDataTableContext, with authentication information for the table to operate on.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Context = New-AzDataTableContext -TableName $TableName -ConnectionString $ConnectionString PS C:\> Clear-AzDataTable -Context $Context

dev:remarks.maml:para: Clear all entities from a table using a connection string.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Context = New-AzDataTableContext -TableName $TableName -StorageAccountName $Name -ManagedIdentity PS C:\> Clear-AzDataTable $Context

dev:remarks.maml:para: Clear all entities from a table using a managed identity.

maml:description.maml:para: Get one or more entities from an Azure Table.
Get either all entities from an Azure Table, or those matching a provided OData filter.
Documentation on querying tables and entities: <https://docs.microsoft.com/en-gb/rest/api/storageservices/querying-tables-and-entities>
A context object created by New-AzDataTableContext, with authentication information for the table to operate on.
Specifies to only get the number of matching entities in the table, and not the data itself.
A context object created by New-AzDataTableContext, with authentication information for the table to operate on.
The OData filter to use in the query. Documentation on querying tables and entities: <https://docs.microsoft.com/en-gb/rest/api/storageservices/querying-tables-and-entities>
Gets only the specified number of objects. Enter the number of objects to get.
One or several names of properties, to specify data to return for the entities.
Ignores the specified number of objects and then gets the remaining objects. Enter the number of objects to skip.
Specifies one or several property names that to sort the entities by. If several properties are provided, the entities are sorted in the order that the property names are provided.
Note that using this parameter may slow down the command a lot when working with large data sets!
A context object created by New-AzDataTableContext, with authentication information for the table to operate on.
Specifies to only get the number of matching entities in the table, and not the data itself.
The OData filter to use in the query. Documentation on querying tables and entities: <https://docs.microsoft.com/en-gb/rest/api/storageservices/querying-tables-and-entities>
Gets only the specified number of objects. Enter the number of objects to get.
One or several names of properties, to specify data to return for the entities.
Ignores the specified number of objects and then gets the remaining objects. Enter the number of objects to skip.
Specifies one or several property names that to sort the entities by. If several properties are provided, the entities are sorted in the order that the property names are provided.
Note that using this parameter may slow down the command a lot when working with large data sets!

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Context = New-AzDataTableContext -TableName $TableName -ConnectionString $ConnectionString PS C:\> $UserEntity = Get-AzDataTableEntity -Filter "FirstName eq 'Bobby' and LastName eq 'Tables'" -Context $Context

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get the user "Bobby Tables" from the table using a connection string.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Context = New-AzDataTableContext -TableName $TableName -ConnectionString $ConnectionString PS C:\> $UserCount = Get-AzDataTableEntity -Filter "LastName eq 'Tables'" -Context $Context -Count

dev:remarks.maml:para: Use the Count parameter to get only the number of users matching the filter, using a connection string.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Context = New-AzDataTableContext -TableName $TableName -ManagedIdentity -StorageAccountName $Name PS C:\> $UserEntities = Get-AzDataTableEntity -Sort 'Id','Age' -First 100 -Skip 500 -Context $Context

dev:remarks.maml:para: Skipping the first 100 entities, get 500 entities sorted by id and age from the table using a managed identity for authorization.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Context = New-AzDataTableContext -TableName $TableName -SharedAccessSignature $SAS PS C:\> $UserEntities = Get-AzDataTableEntity -Property 'FirstName','Age' -Context $Context

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get only the properties "FirstName" and "Age" for all entities found in the table using a shared access signature URL.

maml:description.maml:para: Create a new table.
Create a new table.
A context object created by New-AzDataTableContext, with authentication information for the table to operate on.
A context object created by New-AzDataTableContext, with authentication information for the table to operate on.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Context = New-AzDataTableContext -TableName $TableName -ConnectionString $ConnectionString PS C:\> New-AzDataTable -Context $Context

dev:remarks.maml:para: Create a new table using a connection string for the storage account.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a context object with authentication information for the table to operate on, to be used in other commands.
Creates a context object with authentication information for the table to operate on, to be used in other commands.
Specifies the client id when using a user-assigned managed identity.
Specifies that the command is run by a managed identity (such as in an Azure Function), and authorization will be handled using that identity.
The name of the storage account.
The name of the table.
The connection string to the storage account.
The name of the table.
The table service SAS URL. The table endpoint of the storage account, with the shared access token appended to it.
The name of the table.
The storage account access key.
The name of the storage account.
The name of the table.
The name of the storage account.
The name of the table.
An access token to use for authorization.
Specifies the client id when using a user-assigned managed identity.
The connection string to the storage account.
Specifies that the command is run by a managed identity (such as in an Azure Function), and authorization will be handled using that identity.
The table service SAS URL. The table endpoint of the storage account, with the shared access token appended to it.
The storage account access key.
The name of the storage account.
The name of the table.
An access token to use for authorization.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a context object using the table name and a connection string.
Creates a context object using the table name, storage account name and a storage account access key.
Creates a context object using the table name and a shared access signature URL.
Creates a context object using the table name, storage account name and a managed identity for authorization.
Creates a context object using the table name, storage account name and an access token.

maml:description.maml:para: Delete an existing table.
Delete an existing table.
A context object created by New-AzDataTableContext, with authentication information for the table to operate on.
A context object created by New-AzDataTableContext, with authentication information for the table to operate on.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Context = New-AzDataTableContext -TableName $TableName -ConnectionString $ConnectionString PS C:\> Remove-AzDataTable -Context $Context

dev:remarks.maml:para: Remove an existing table using a connection string for the storage account.

maml:description.maml:para: Remove one or more entities from an Azure Table.
Remove one or more entities from an Azure Table, as an array of either Hashtables or PSObjects, based on PartitionKey and RowKey.
A context object created by New-AzDataTableContext, with authentication information for the table to operate on.
The entities to remove from the table.
A context object created by New-AzDataTableContext, with authentication information for the table to operate on.
The entities to remove from the table.
This cmdlet takes either an array of hashtables or psobjects as input to the Entity parameter, which can also be provided through the pipeline.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Entity = @{ PartitionKey = 'Example'; RowKey = '1' } PS C:\> Remove-AzDataTableEntity -Entity $Entity -TableName $TableName -StorageAccountName $Name -StorageAccountKey $Key

dev:remarks.maml:para: Remove the entity with PartitionKey "Example" and RowKey "1", using the storage account name and an access key.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $UserEntity = Get-AzDataTableEntity -Filter "FirstName eq 'Bobby' and LastName eq 'Tables'" -TableName $TableName -ConnectionString $ConnectionString PS C:\> Remove-AzDataTableEntity -Entity $UserEntity -TableName $TableName -StorageAccountName $Name -StorageAccountKey $Key

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get the user "Bobby Tables" from the table using a connection string, then remove the user using the storage account name and an access key.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Users = Get-AzDataTableEntity -Filter "LastName eq 'Tables'" -TableName $TableName -ConnectionString $ConnectionString PS C:\> Remove-AzDataTableEntity -Entity $Users -TableName $TableName -StorageAccountName $Name -StorageAccountKey $Key

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets all users with the last name "Tables" from the table using a connection string, then removes the users using the storage account name and an access key.

maml:description.maml:para: Update one or more entities in an Azure Table.
Update one or more entities already existing in an Azure Table, as an array of either Hashtables or PSObjects.
For adding and overwriting, also see the command Add-AzDataTableEntity.
The PartitionKey and RowKey cannot be updated.
A context object created by New-AzDataTableContext, with authentication information for the table to operate on.
The entities to update in the table.
A context object created by New-AzDataTableContext, with authentication information for the table to operate on.
The entities to update in the table.
This cmdlet takes either an array of hashtables or psobjects as input to the Entity parameter, which can also be provided through the pipeline.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $UserEntity = Get-AzDataTableEntity -Filter "FirstName eq 'Bobby'" -TableName $TableName -ConnectionString $ConnectionString PS C:\> $UserEntity['LastName'] = 'Tables' PS C:\> Update-AzDataTableEntity -Entity $UserEntity -TableName $TableName -ConnectionString $ConnectionString

dev:remarks.maml:para: Update the last name of the user "Bobby" to "Tables" using a connection string.
